skill.name: multi-agent-patterns
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "design multi-agent system", "implement supervisor pattern", "create swarm architecture", "coordinate multiple agents", or mentions multi-agent patterns, context isolation, agent handoffs, sub-agents, or parallel agent execution.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when the user asks to "design multi-agent system", "implement supervisor p...
skill.author: muratcankoylan

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation and reference library skill. All static findings are false positives: code block examples in markdown are not executable shell commands; task coordination patterns are not cryptographic algorithms or reconnaissance; no actual network calls, file I/O, or external commands exist in the codebase.

content.value_statement: Single-agent systems face context limits, sequential processing bottlenecks, and inflexible tool configurations. This skill provides patterns for distributing work across multiple AI agents with explicit coordination, handoff protocols, and failure handling.
actual_capabilities: Implement supervisor/orchestrator pattern for centralized multi-agent control
Design peer-to-peer swarm architecture with explicit handoff protocols
Create hierarchical agent layers for strategic, planning, and execution tasks
Build consensus mechanisms with weighted voting and debate protocols
Handle agent failures with circuit breakers and retry logic
Apply context isolation strategies for partitioned agent contexts
limitations: Does not provide actual agent runtime execution environment
Requires integration with framework like LangGraph, AutoGen, or CrewAI
Python library examples need adaptation to your specific use case
Does not include pre-built agent implementations

use_cases.title: Build production agent systems
use_cases.description: Design scalable multi-agent systems with proper coordination, failure recovery, and context partitioning.

use_cases.title: Explore coordination patterns
use_cases.description: Experiment with supervisor, swarm, and hierarchical patterns to understand multi-agent trade-offs.

use_cases.title: Integrate agent workflows
use_cases.description: Add multi-agent coordination to existing applications with explicit handoffs and consensus mechanisms.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Pattern Selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me design a multi-agent system for [TASK]. Should I use supervisor pattern, swarm pattern, or hierarchical pattern? Explain the trade-offs.

prompt_templates.title: Supervisor Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to implement a supervisor agent that coordinates [NUMBER] worker agents for [TASK] using [FRAMEWORK].

prompt_templates.title: Handoff Protocol
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an explicit handoff protocol for transferring context from agent [A] to agent [B] when [CONDITION] occurs.

prompt_templates.title: Failure Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement circuit breaker and retry logic for a multi-agent system where agents can fail during long-running [TASK_TYPE].

output_examples.input: Design a multi-agent system for conducting competitive research on a topic
output: Architecture Choice: Supervisor pattern recommended for structured research workflow
Agent Roles: Supervisor coordinates Researcher, Analyzer, and Writer agents
Handoff Protocol: Research complete triggers handoff to Analyzer; Analysis complete triggers handoff to Writer
Consensus: Weighted voting on research findings based on source confidence scores
Failure Handling: Circuit breaker disables individual agents after 3 failures; tasks rerouted to backup agents

output_examples.input: How do I implement a swarm architecture where agents can hand off tasks to each other?
output: Core Pattern: Peer-to-peer communication without central supervisor
Handoff Mechanism: Agents return handoff target as function result
State Transfer: Context passed through explicit transfer protocol
Convergence: Define clear termination conditions and shared goals
No Central Bottleneck: Each agent can communicate with any other agent directly

output_examples.input: What are the token costs of multi-agent versus single-agent approaches?
output: Single Agent Chat: 1x baseline token usage
Single Agent with Tools: Approximately 4x baseline
Multi-Agent System: Approximately 15x baseline for complex coordination
Key Insight: Parallelization often justifies higher token costs for time-sensitive tasks

best_practices: Design for context isolation as the primary benefit of multi-agent systems
Implement explicit handoff protocols with state passing between agents
Use weighted voting or debate protocols instead of simple majority for consensus
anti_patterns: Creating sub-agents based on organizational roles rather than context isolation needs
Allowing sub-agents full context delegation that defeats the purpose of separation
Skipping validation of agent outputs before passing to downstream consumers

faq.question: Which framework should I use?
faq.answer: LangGraph for state machine approaches, AutoGen for conversational patterns, CrewAI for hierarchical role-based flows.

faq.question: How many agents do I need?
faq.answer: Start with 2-3 agents. More agents increase coordination overhead and token costs significantly.

faq.question: Can this integrate with my existing system?
faq.answer: Yes. The patterns are framework-agnostic. Adapt the coordination logic to your agent runtime.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This skill is prompt-based. Your data never leaves your session. Python library runs locally only.

faq.question: Why are my agents not coordinating?
faq.answer: Check your handoff protocols, ensure message queues are draining, and verify circuit breakers are not active.

faq.question: How is this different from single-agent?
faq.answer: Multi-agent enables parallel processing, context isolation, and specialized configurations at the cost of higher token usage.
